Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story:
The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets, and my wipers struggled to keep the windshield clear. My passenger, a businessman clutching his passport, kept glancing at his watch and urging me to go faster. “Please, I can’t miss this flight,” he pleaded, his voice tight with anxiety. As a taxi driver, I felt the weight of his expectation—get him to the airport safely and on time, no matter the weather. But the roads were slick, and every turn of the wheel demanded my full attention.

At the same time, I was supposed to have a ten-minute window for quiet meditation, a promise I’d made to myself to nurture my Buddhist practice. I could feel the tension in my chest, the urge to close my eyes and breathe, to let go of the stress and be present. But the storm, the traffic, and my passenger’s desperation pulled me in the opposite direction. My hands gripped the steering wheel, torn between the demands of the road and the call for inner stillness, caught in the storm both outside and within.
